abstract.para: The following example shows how to set up a timer that triggers the helloworld.sh shell script after boot time and repeats its execution every 24 hours relative to its activation time. It also runs Monday to Friday at 10am.

step.para: Create the file /etc/systemd/system/helloworld.service with the following content:
This is a &systemd; service file that tells systemd which application to run.
Create the file /etc/systemd/system/helloworld.timer with the following content:
step.screen:
[Unit] Description="Run helloworld.service 5min after boot and every 24 hours relative to activation time"
[Timer] OnBootSec=5min OnUnitActiveSec=24h OnCalendar=Mon..Fri 10:00 Unit=helloworld.service
[Install] WantedBy=multi-user.target
step.para: This is the timer file that controls when to activate the respective service file.
Verify that the files you created above contain no errors:
If the command returns no output, the files have passed the verification successfully.
Activates the timer for the current session only.
Enable the timer to make sure that it is activated on boot:

example.para: This is a minimum required for a service file to work. For advanced configuration, refer to Managing systemd targets with systemctl.

note.title: Service files for timer do not require an INSTALL section
note.para: &systemd; service files normally contain an [Install] section, that determines one or more targets for a service to load. This section is not required in service files for timers, since this information is provided with the timer file.

example.title: The timer file
example.screen:
[Unit] Description="Run helloworld.service 5min after boot and every 24 hours relative to activation time""
[Timer] OnBootSec=5min OnUnitActiveSec=24h OnCalendar=Mon..Fri *-*-* 10:00 Unit=helloworld.service
[Install] WantedBy=multi-user.target

callout.para: A brief description explaining the timer file's purpose.
Specifies a timer that triggers the service five minutes after the system boot.
Specifies a timer that triggers the service 24 hours after the service has been activated (that is, the timer will trigger the service once a day).
Specifies a timer that triggers the service at fixed points in time (in this example, Monday to Friday at 10 am).
The &systemd; target in which the timer gets activated. For more information on &systemd; targets refer to ???.
